The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
Given a subset \(U \subset \bar{K}^{n}\), the corresponding ideal \(I(U)\) in the polynomial ring \(K[X]\) consists of all polynomials that vanish on \(U\).
Does the concept of a/an Domain need to be defined for a definition of a/an Ideal corresponding to a subset to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The concept of an Ideal corresponding to a subset involves defining a set of polynomials that vanish on a given subset of a space, specifically \\(U \\subset \\bar{K}^{n}\\). This definition inherently involves polynomial functions and their behavior on the subset \\(U\\). However, the definition of an Ideal does not require the concept of a domain as defined in the context of function theory, where a domain is the set of all possible inputs for which a function is defined. The definition of an Ideal corresponding to a subset is more related to algebraic structures in polynomial rings and does not directly involve the function-theoretic concept of a domain. Therefore, the concept of a domain as defined (set of all possible input values for a function) is not necessary to define an Ideal corresponding to a subset, which is more focused on properties of polynomials and algebraic geometry.
